Review
Recent developments in palladium (nano)catalysts supported on polymers for selective and sustainable oxidation processes
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ccr.2019.06.010 0010-8545/ 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: mahmoudnasr81@gmail.com, m.nasrollahzadeh@qom.ac.ir (M. Nasrollahzadeh), varma.rajender@epa.gov (R.S. Varma).
Mahmoud Nasrollahzadeh a,⇑, Mohaddeseh Sajjadi a, Mohammadreza Shokouhimehr b, Rajender S. Varma c,⇑ aDepartment of Chemistry, Faculty of Science, University of Qom, Qom 37185-359, Iran bDepartment of Materials Science and Engineering, Research Institute of Advanced Materials, Seoul National University, Seoul 08826, Republic of Korea cRegional Centre of Advanced Technologies and Materials, Department of Physical Chemistry, Faculty of Science, Palacky University, Šlechtitelů 27, 783 71 Olomouc, Czech Republic
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 7 March 2019 Accepted 17 June 2019
Keywords: Oxidation reactions Polymer-supported Pd catalysts Pd nanoparticles Pd complexes
a b s t r a c t
This review describes the recent advances in the fabrication, characterization and applications of palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs)/complexes supported on polymers. Nanostructured materials and NPs of various natures, shapes and sizes in combination with polymers, provide unique physicochemical properties and significant potential applications. An overview in catalysis encompassing the preparation of polymer-supported Pd nanocatalysts and Pd complexes for the oxidation of alcohols, olefins, alkenes, carbon monoxide, etc. is presented. Heterogeneous oxidation catalysis, a vital tool in chemical synthesis and transformations, includes the development of various synthetic strategies for the fabrication of Pd-based catalysts; eminent role played by polymer supports in the morphological and structural properties of the ensuing catalysts, is highlighted.
2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
There has always been an abiding interest in the oxidation transformations, one of the most important and powerful routes both for industrial manufacturing and fundamental research in organic synthesis and manipulations. Oxidation of alcohols, carbon monoxide, olefins, alkenes and other organic substrates to valueadded oxygenic compounds is an important and pivotal reaction [1–10]. Unfortunately, various oxidative transformations have been traditionally carried out using hazardous, and toxic oxidants such as permanganates, organic peroxides, chromates, etc.
Diverse studies have been undertaken on the catalytic oxidation using transition metal/metal oxide based catalysts from the economic and environmental perspective. During last 15 years, there have been many research efforts to introduce novel, and ecofriendly catalytic systems for the oxidation transformations; the replacement of conventional methods has continued with newer catalytic conversions using various metallic catalysts under clean and greener conditions. These catalytic systems are often homogeneous and the catalysts cannot be separated or recovered from the reaction. Researchers have recently focused great attention to heterogeneous catalytic systems to overcome the drawbacks of homogeneous counterparts due to their regenerability, reusability, ease of handling, and insolubility in solvents [11–20].
Among various catalysts, metal oxides or metal nanoparticles (NPs) generally display higher catalytic activity and potential applications, in contrast to their bulky counterparts, owing to their small sizes, shapes and high surface to volume ratios that bestow them with unique quantum properties [21–27]. Indeed, utilization of transition metals in organic synthesis is indispensable. They not only enhance the reaction rate of the organic transformations, but also facilitate the generation of various products with high chemoand regio-selectivity. However, they are associated with some critical drawbacks such as their high-cost, toxicity, requirements for non-commercial ligands, separation and leaching of the catalytic species which are very unfavorable from the pharmaceutical point of view and greatly limits their practical applicability. Therefore, contiguous investigations for the preparation of advanced catalysts with improved properties and characteristic is very important for the future industrial development. Among different metal catalysts, palladium (Pd) NPs or Pd-based complexes are extensively used in various organic reactions due to their unique properties [28–34]. Pd has been considered to have little environmental impact and regarded as low toxicity material as conventionally measured (e.g. Ld50) [35–37]. However, recent research suggests that higher doses of Pd could be poisonous and may be carcinogenic; PdCl2 is toxic, harmful if swallowed, inhaled or absorbed through the skin and does cause bone marrow, liver and kidney damage in laboratory animals [35–37].
To avoid the likely agglomeration of the NPs and the overstoichiometric use of Pd reagents and enhance the durability and
reusability of the metallic catalysts, the selection of a suitable, safe and recyclable support are the most significant parameters for the design and synthesis of heterogeneous catalysts or complexes. Different types of polymers have been utilized as hosts and rigid supports for Pd species because of their unique properties and prowess to accelerate the rate of oxidation transformations. In the past decades, metallic nanocomposite-based polymeric supports have garnered interest because of their high reusability and chemical stability, open pore network with three dimensional structure, uniform and interconnected pores, high porosity and surface area, among others thus providing a suitable platform for the immobilization of components and interactive surfaces of reactants and catalysts [38–44]. In general, such polymers can be of wideranging composites and structural forms, with varying molecular chains, and sizes, thus rendering them ideal candidates for the deposition and stabilization of nanostructured materials. Additionally, these compounds do not generally swell in organic solvents and can be separated from the reaction mixtures and reused many times with significant efficiency.
Pd-based nanocatalysts or Pd complexes supported on polymers can be obtained using metallic or ionic Pd via various heterogenization processes. In this regards, several researchers have investigated the design and fabrication of Pd catalysts on a variety of polymeric materials including metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), covalent organic frameworks (COFs), polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), triptycene, polypyrrole, polyaniline, polystyrene (PS), poly (ethylene glycol) (PEG), poly(vinylidene fluoride), poly-acrylonitrileN,N-dimethylacrylamide-ethylenedimethacrylate, resin, etc. In general, assorted polymers could be used to fabricate new, eco-friendly and effective materials with ideal thermomechanical characteristics as favorable alternatives for conventional catalyst supports; oxidative transformations on polymer-supported Pd catalysts have been continually evolving in view of their environmentally benign character.
This review highlights the salient advantageous features of polymer supports in the design of a safe and new generation of catalysts. Herein, the application of polymeric supports to prepare polymer-supported Pd NPs and Pd complexes are discussed and a better understanding of their synthetic applications in oxidation transformations are provided.

sections.heading: 2. Proposed mechanism for Pd-catalyzed oxidation reactions
sections.text:
There have been several published reports on the oxidation reactions using Pd-based catalysts in recent years. However, only a few attempts have been made to delineate the mechanism for the oxidation reaction in presence of oxidants. Some common oxidants are summarized in Table 1; a fewwere used in organic redox, combustion reactions, and while some others retain rather explosive character.
Table 1 Common oxidizing agents and the ensuing products.
Entry Oxidizing agent Product(s)
1 Oxygen (O2) Various, including the oxides, H2O and CO2 2 Ozone (O3) Various, including ketones, aldehydes, and H2O 3 Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and other inorganic peroxides, Fenton’s reagent Various, including oxides and H2O 4 Fluorine (F2), chlorine (Cl2), and other halogens F , Cl , Br and I , [I3] 5 Nitric acid (HNO3) and nitrate compounds NO and NO2 6 Sulfuric acid (H2SO4) Oxidized sulfur species, S, H2O 7 Sulphur dioxide (SO2) S (Claus process, ultramarine production, more commonly reducing agent) 8 Peroxymonosulfuric acid (H2SO5) H2O and SO42 9 Chlorite, chlorate, perchlorate, and other analogous halogen compounds Cl , H2O 10 Hypochlorite and other hypohalite compounds, including household bleach (NaClO) Cl , H2O 11 Sodium bismuthate Various, including ketones, carboxylic acid, and CO2 12 Permanganate compounds such as potassium permanganate Mn2+ (acidic) or MnO2 (basic) 13 Hexavalent chromium compounds such as chromic and dichromic acids and
chromium trioxide, pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC), and chromate/dichromate compounds
Cr3+, H2O
14 Tl(III) thallic compounds Tl(I) thallous compounds, in organic lab scale synthesis 15 Ruthenium tetroxide (RuO4) and osmium tetroxide (OsO4) In organic lab scale synthesis
An oxidizing agent that can cause combustion is considered a dangerous and hazardous material and are marked with a specific hazard symbol. However, not every oxidant is hazardous. For example, K2Cr2O7 is not considered a dangerous substance in terms of transport. There are several quenching agents for the removal of commonly known toxic oxidants with varying procedures for their smothering action such as enzymes, reducing agents or metal oxides after eventual pH adjustment and filtration steps [45]. For example, different types of the catalase enzyme as well as manganese dioxide, sodium thiosulfate, sodium sulfite, sodium nitrite and ascorbic acid were used in studied bioassays for quenching of oxidants such as persulfate, hydrogen peroxide and peroxymonosulfate. One of common oxidants is hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)) that is used in various industrial processes and harmful to human health. The simplest method to remove highly watersoluble Cr(VI) entails its conversion to low water-soluble Cr(III) in the presence of low cost and ecofriendly reducing agents such as formic acid (HCOOH) [46–48]. To overcome the problems of toxicity and work-up associated with many inorganic oxidants, it would be advantageous to develop a catalytic supported oxidant. Towards this aim, poly[vinyl(pyridinium chlorochromate)] has been used as a recyclable mild oxidant for primary, secondary, benzylic and allylic alcohols to carbonyl compounds [49].
Lately, there have been several reports on the Pd-catalyzed oxidation reactions using molecular oxygen in the absence of co-oxidants and/or redox-active co-catalysts. The catalytic mechanism for Pd oxidase catalysis is usually identical to that of the oxidation reactions, which could be separated into two distinct half reactions (Scheme 1). Although, the first aerobic Pd-catalyzed alcohol oxidations needed co-catalysts e.g. copper salts that can be limited in their general practicality [50]. Several attempts have
Scheme 1. Catalytic cycle for the Pd-catalyzed aerobic oxidation reactions into two half reactions.
been recently made to elucidate the mechanistic features of these processes. For example, one of the most versatile and useful catalytic systems is Pd(OAc)2/pyridine-catalyzed alcohol oxidations [51–56] which are conducted aerobically at 80 C; Stahl and coworkers reported kinetic studies via a gas-uptake approach and 1H NMR spectroscopy [52–56]. The turnover-limiting substrate oxidation was described using Pd(II)/pyridine proceeded through a four-step procedures (Scheme 2), namely (i) preparation of complex by using alcohol and palladium(II) acetate; (ii) alcoholysis of as-prepared complex to form Pd(II)-alkoxides; (iii) the pyridine dissociation to fabricate a (three)coordinate intermediate; and (iv) irreversible b-H elimination.
In another similar work, Sigman et al. developed experimental and computational studies for Pd(OAc)2/trimethylamine system to oxidize a variety of primary/secondary alcohols at ambient temperature using of O2 (1 atm.) [51] with underlying mechanism elucidated (Scheme 3) [57]. Based on kinetic studies, KIE experiments, and DFT calculations, the rate-limiting step is identified as alcohol deprotonation, whereas b-H elimination step was the rate-limiting for Pd(II)/pyridine-catalyzed oxidation of alcohols.
Mechanistic investigations were performed by the groups of Stoltz [58], Sigman [59] and Stahl [60,61,53] wherein overall accepted mechanistic suggestions towards the oxidation of alcohols is depicted in Scheme 4, in which alcoholic substrate initially coordinates with LnPdIIX2 catalyst to produce intermediate (Step A). The presence of an external base promotes the alcohol deprotonation step to generate PdII-alkoxide intermediate (Step B). Subsequently, PdII-hydride intermediate (Step C) synthesized
Scheme 2. The proposed mechanism for the Pd/pyridine-catalyzed alcohol oxidation.
Scheme 3. The proposed mechanism for the Pd/TEA-catalyzed alcohol oxidation.
Scheme 4. The commonly accepted mechanism for the aerobic Pd-catalyzed alcohols oxidation.
Scheme 5. The catalytic accepted mechanism for the Wacker oxidation reaction.
via a b-hydride elimination step, readily releases Pd0 species (Step D) by the reductive elimination step. In the final step, the cycle can be completed via a reoxidation step using O2 and HX (Steps E and F).
Additionally, for aerobic alcohol oxidation, the original utilization of molecular oxygen as a most interesting terminal oxidant in Pd-catalyzed oxidation processes has been described in 1959 by Smidt et al. [62]. They confirmed that in the presence of the combined Pd(II) catalyst with Cu(II) salts, the ethylene oxidation to acetyl aldehyde was attained under an aerobic atmosphere. There have been several published reviews on the recent progress of the Wacker oxidation process using molecular oxygen, in which the need for various co-catalysts was obviated via the use of ligands to stabilize/coordinate the neutral Pd [63–66]. In 1998, Sheldon et al. reported one of the initial examples of the use of a direct molecular O2-coupled Wacker oxidation under co-catalystfree conditions [67,68]. Generally, the traditional Wacker oxidation involves PdCl2, CuCl2 in DMF-water solvent system under O2 conditions. In this classical system, the CuCl2/O2 combination may be used as the best-known co-oxidant mixture (Scheme 5), while a
variety of other reagents can be also used namely polyoxometallates, stoichiometric Cu(II) salts, benzoquinone, and organic and inorganic peroxides [69,70]. In the Wacker process, the main step is the LnPd(0) reoxidization into active LnPdIIX2 species by employing copper salts as oxidant.

sections.heading: 3. Polymer-supported Pd NPs in oxidation reactions
3.1. Oxidation of carbon monoxide
sections.text: Catalytic carbon monoxide (CO) oxidation reactions have important ecological, health, and industrial impacts owing to the CO toxicity and have been widely considered as the most effective process for the removal of CO from indoor air and H2 stream utilized in fuel cell applications [71].

sections.heading: 3.1.1. Pd-based nanocatalysts supported on MOFs polymers
sections.text:
The development of novel and efficient, low temperature CO catalytic oxidations is of huge interest in diverse research areas including fuel cell and the remediation of toxic gases that are released via combustion processes to atmosphere [71–73]. One of the simple methods for the fabrication of separable metal nanocatalysts is their incorporation as active species of various sizes and shapes within the highly porous crystalline polymer MOFs that has well-defined cavities or channels. In this regard, metallic and bimetallic NPs were stabilized on MIL-101 crystals by El-Shall and co-workers in 2009, who prepared a series of separable Pd and Pd/Cu based nanocatalysts stabilized on MIL-101 polymer and evaluated the catalytic activities of the resulting catalysts in CO oxidation [74]. MIL-101 polymer, a chromium-based MOF having the general formula of {Cr3F(H2O)2O[(O2C)-C6H4-(CO2)]3 nH2O}, has a large surface area and mesoporous nature with available diameters of 2.9 and 3.4 nm.
Pd@MIL-101 catalyst was attained by simultaneous activation of MIL-101 pores and the rapid Pd nitrate reduction using microwave irradiation in the presence of hydrazine hydrate as the reducing agent. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) analysis of the nanocatalyst showed the particles with the average particle sizes
of 2–3 nm, which are integrated within the pores and larger particles with diameters of about 4–6 nm immobilized on the exterior surfaces of MIL-101. According to the obtained results, the synthesized novel Pd@MIL-101 with 2.9 wt% Pd loading exhibited excellent catalytic activity in the low temperature CO oxidation reaction (full conversion at 107 C) under aerobic conditions (Fig. 1). Also, the Pd@MIL-101 can be recovered and reused several times without significant loss of its catalytic activity. The XRD patterns before and after the reaction revealed that the Pd@MIL-101 retained its crystallinity throughout.
However, there are various reports on the CO oxidation reactions with MOF-based catalysts [75,76]. In this context, a low temperature CO oxidation was accomplished using a catalyst supported on cerium-based MOFs synthesized by Lin et al. [77]. They reported a facile and effective microwave irradiation procedure for the incorporation of Pd NPs within the Ce-MOF (Pd/CeMOF) and evaluated them in moderate temperature CO oxidation (370 K) and low temperature capture of CO2 gas (273 K) (Fig. 2). Cerium metal cluster assembly using benzene 1,3,5- tricarboxylate (BTC) as the organic linker was based on a polymeric structure {[Ce(BTC)(H2O)] DMF}n, which provided a good probability for the deposition of a reactive CO oxidation catalyst e.g. Pd NPs in which the CO molecules could be effectively adsorbed. TEM images of the prepared catalyst reveal that the spherical particles with a diameter of 4.6 ± 2.2 nm are prevailing on the Ce-MOF crystals surface (needle shaped particles, 2–6 mm).
Fig. 2. Effective CO oxidation and CO2 capture at low temperature. Reprinted from Ref. (C Inc., reprinted with permission) [77].
The catalytic activity and efficiency of Pd/Ce-MOF catalyst in CO oxidation were considerably higher than the previously reported metal-based nanocatalysts supported on MOFs, which is caused by the subsistence of Ce(III) and Ce(IV) species in the MOF scaffold. Subsequently, Pd NPs immobilized on the surface of Ce-MOF preserve oxygen in the preparation of a thin Pd oxide layer as well as Ce(III)/Ce(IV) centers. In CO oxidation at 373 K, O2 could be easily released from these reservoirs and then at lower temperatures of 273 K, Pd/Ce-MOF nanocatalyst possess a considerable CO2 uptake (3.5 mmol/g). Upon completion of the reaction, the Pd/Ce-MOF nanocatalyst was separated from the reaction mixture and reused for next runs.
3.1.2. Pd NPs supported on PVP/c-alumina Polymers such as PVP have shown the ability to protect the metal particles by preventing their sintering; forming stable colloidal suspensions and depositing precious metals on the alumina surface, are some of the additional attributes. Miguel-García et al. presented a facile process to synthesize Pd NPs protected by PVP as a capping agent and depositing the PVP coated Pd NP colloidal suspensions onto c-alumina (Pd-PVP/Al2O3) [78]. The extended protection accorded to Pd NPs by PVP and the enhanced stability against agglomeration for a period of over a year was noteworthy.
The obtained catalyst was used successfully in the oxidation (PrOx) of CO reactions under excess H2 flow up to 200 C. It has been shown that the aging duration of colloidal suspensions, similar to the time spent between deposition and colloid fabrication, can change the supporting polymer’s ability to protect the NPs, thereby moderating their catalytic activity and selectivity; maximum CO conversion and selectivity towards CO were 40 and 26%, respectively.
3.1.3. Pd-based nanocatalysts supported on microporous organic polymers
Microporous organic polymers, compared to MOFs, are highly versatile materials having comparatively stable covalent bonds (such as C-H and C-C bonds), and display improved stability in practical reaction conditions, which commonly degrade coordination frameworks. A series of heterogeneous Pd NPs catalysts were supported on new triptycene-functionalized microporous polymers (Pd/NTP) and evaluated in CO oxidation reactions by Liang and co-workers [79]. The uniformly monodispersed Pd NPs catalysts on an NTP support were synthesized by reducing PdCl42 by NaBH4 and H2 utilizing the gas bubbling assisted membrane reduction process (Fig. 3). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and TEM images of the acquired catalyst show highly monodispersed NPs with an average diameter of 2.7–5 nm on the porous framework of NTP.
opyright 2017 The American Chemical Society and Division of Chemical Education,
The new triptycene polymer (NTP) was synthesized based on covalent C–C bond coupling by Ni(0)-catalyzed Yamamoto-type Ullmann reaction between 2,7,14-tribromotriptycene groups in DMF at 85 C (Scheme 6). The lowest temperature oxidation for the complete conversion of CO was 160 C in the presence of Pd/ NTP (3.0 wt% and 3.2 nm) as the catalyst (Table 2). As shown in Table 2, catalytic activity for 50 and 100% CO oxidation is very low (Entry 5). TEM image of the catalyst used for CO oxidation reaction also indicates that the particle size distribution of NTP supported Pd does not change.

sections.heading: 3.2. Oxidation of alcohols
sections.text: The oxidation of alcohols to carbonyl derivatives is one of the most widely used reaction in organic syntheses. There are numerous reports on the oxidation of alcohols using Pd-based catalysts [80–119]; oxide-supported Pd catalysts and their use in the oxidation of alcohols are summarized in Table 3. Earlier reported methods for the oxidation of alcohols suffer from drawbacks namely the use of expensive and toxic reagents, harsh reaction conditions, low yields, longer reaction times, tedious work-up, difficulty in obtaining and/or preparing the starting materials. Therefore, the development of more efficient and convenient methods for the oxidation of alcohols under mild conditions still remains an active research area. In this section, some recent developments using polymerbased Pd catalysts are provided.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. Pd NPs supported on polymers
sections.text:
Cross-esterification oxidation of various aliphatic and benzyl alcohols with molecular O2 using polymer-supported Pd catalysts

provides a procedure for the stabilization of Pd NPs or Pd alloys on the surfaces of polymer supports [120–122]. Along these lines, Kumar and co-workers have prepared polymer supported Pd NPs (Pd@PS) and evaluated their catalytic activity in esterification reaction of benzyl alcohols and oxidative condensation [123]. SEM, SEM-EDS, TEM, and HRTEM of the catalysts showed the impregnation of Pd NPs with average size of 2–5 nm and interplanar distance of 0.19 and 0.22 nm form the support materials; the FFT image of selected region showed fcc arrangement of Pd nanocrystal and TEM image of catalyst revealed no change in Pd size on the support surface after five consecutive runs.
The catalyst presented high activity in the selective oxidative condensation and esterification reactions of aryl/alkyl alcohols for efficient synthesis of acetate esters (AEs) and aldehyde conjugate/s (AC/s) via control over the reaction conditions (Scheme 7). A wide range of ethanol and benzyl alcohols have been obtained as substrates for the preparation of AC/s products in the presence of Pd@PS catalyst in K2CO3, oxygen and 1,4-dioxane at 60 C in good yield. Furthermore, Pd@PS has been used for pioneering oxidative esterification for AEs preparation from alcohols using
linked microporous polymer (NTP).
Scheme 7. Oxidative condensation and esterification reactions catalyzed by Pd@PS.
NaOtBu as the base in 1,4-dioxane at 125 C. Reusability evaluation was performed for the oxidative esterification reaction of 3- methoxylbenzyl alcohol. The catalyst could be separated after completion of the reaction and reused over five runs without any significant loss of activity.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. Pd-based nanocatalysts supported on MOFs polymers
sections.text:
One of the techniques for the development of MOF supported metal NPs based catalysts is the modification of MOFs by changing the metal ions or the coordinated organic ligands. In this regard, Pd NPs supported on Fe-MIL-101-NH2 and cerium bimetallic NPsbased catalysts functionalized with a neocuproine ligand (Pd-Ce/ Fe-MIL-101–N=CHNeocuproine) were synthesized by Li and coworkers [124]. The grafting of neocuproine based functional ligand onto Fe-MIL-101-NH2 is based on the formation of an amide bond and the treatment of this neocuproine functionalized Fe-MIL-
Scheme 8. Synthesis of functionalized Fe
101with Pd(OAc)2 and Ce(acac)3 salts (acac = acetylacetonate) culminating in the preparation of a reusable Pd-Ce nanocatalyst (Scheme 8). The morphology and structure of Fe-MIL-101-NH2 could be slightly altered when the reaction is carried out for a longer period of time, but the crystal structure remains unchanged. TEM and SEM micrographs of the synthesized catalyst show mainly spherical particles possessing an average diameter of 5 nm, which are well dispersed on the octagonal support.
The efficiency of hybrid materials was appraised by the selective oxidation conversions of glycerol to produce the corresponding 1,3-dihydroxyacetone in acetonitrile/water at 60 C and 20 psi pressure. Additionally, Pd-Ce/Fe-MIL-101-N=CHNeocuproine nanocatalyst was utilized in the oxidation reactions of other alcohols such as ethanol, benzyl alcohols and 1,5-pentanediol to form the corresponding aldehydes and ketones. Furthermore, the supported catalyst can be recycled with negligible decrease in activity.
-MIL-101-NH2 supported Pd-Ce NPs.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Pd nanoalloys supported on polymers
sections.text:
Direct ethanol fuel cells (DEFCs), which consumes ethanol as a low cost and abundant liquid fuel, can be considered a promising system representing an energy conversion device for portable and automotive electronic applications due to high energy density, easy refilling, low process temperature, and non-toxic gaseous fuels [125,126]. Ethanol oxidation reactions have drawn increasing attention in DEFCs given the renewability attributes of ethanol and high amount of energy stored in gasohol E85. A facile, and highly efficient method for the oxidation of ethanol entails the application of Pd or Pd-based catalysts with high efficiency and good anti-CO toxic ability; Pd nanoalloys have been stabilized on conducting polymer nanostructures.
Ghosh and co-workers in 2017 synthesized a series of new generation bimetallic and trimetallic nanoalloy based catalysts with tunable compositions (e.g. Pd-Au, Pd-Pt-Au, Pd-Pt), incorporated on polypyrrole (PPy) nanofibers and investigated them for electrocatalytic application in DEFC [127]. The PPy nanofiber was synthesized via surfactant-mediated soft template and the catalysts were prepared following the addition of Au(III) acetate, Pd(II) acetylacetonate, and Pt(II) acetylacetonate salts. Pd-Pt/PPy, Pd-Au/PPy and Pd-Pt-Au/PPy catalysts could be synthesized by in situ nucleation and growth of metal NPs on the surface polymer nanofiber through a radiolysis method without any use of reducing agents at room temperature (Fig. 4). HRTEM and TEM images of the prepared nanohybrids demonstrated PPy nanofibers (50–65 nm) with a high and uniform coverage by particles with a diameter of 2–8 nm.
Ethanol oxidation reactions were investigated in the presence of Pd/PPy, Pd89Pt11/PPy, and Pd30Pt29Au41/PPy as the catalyst under alkaline conditions (Fig. 5); the as-synthesized Pd30Pt29Au41/PPy ( 8 nm) nanocatalyst exhibited high electrocatalytic activity, high long term stability and excellent recyclability in the electrooxidation of ethanol in alkaline conditions. The superior catalytic performance and stability of ultra-small Pd30Pt29Au41/PPy nanohybrids have been achieved owing to the fabrication of Pt-Pd-Au heterojunctions having excellent synergistic effects between three metal
Fig. 4. Proposed diagram for the radiolytic preparation of nanohybrids. (a) Synthesis of p nanofibers. (Copyright 2015 The American Chemical Society and Division of Chemica
NPs in the nanoalloy composition and strong interactions between metal NPs and PPy nanofibers. The main advantages of Pd nanoalloy/polymer hybrid materials are the stability and recyclability of the electrocatalysts.
3.2.4. Pd NPs or nanoflowers supported on conducting polymers The surface modification of conducting polymers with Pd NPs has been studied. For instance, the simple preparation of hollow polypyrrole (PPy) nanospheres as solid supports to stabilize Pd nanocatalysts (Pd NPs@hollow-PPy) has been reported by Bai and co-workers [128]; Pd NPs@hollow-PPy catalyst was prepared in several steps and showed a potential application in DEFC (Fig. 6).
olymer nanofibers with oxidative template. (b) Formation of metal NPs on polymer l Education, Inc., reprinted with permission) [127].
PPy@PS core-shell was quickly prepared via a facile chemical polymerization of pyrrole and through sulfonation of PS as a sacrificial template to obtain a single layer of PPy spheres on the PS particles surface. The PS core was removed carefully using toluene as a solvent and then the single layer hollow PPy spheres were prepared. In the final step, PPy hollow spheres were treated with Pd(II) chloride using KBH4 in ethanol-water to deliver the desired Pd NPs@hollow-PPy catalyst. TEM images of the catalyst displayed nearly monodisperse spherical particles having an average size of 2.3 nm.
The as-prepared Pd NPs@hollow-PPy acts as a highly efficient and stable nanocatalyst in ethanol electrooxidation reactions wherein the electrochemical performances of the catalysts were evaluated by cyclic voltammetry measurements in 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte. Fig. 7 depicts the cyclic voltammetry curves acquired without CO adsorbed (solid curves) and with CO adsorbed (dashed curves) onto the catalysts, of the as-prepared (a) Pd/hollow-PPy, (b) Pd/solid-PPy and (c) Pd/Vulcan XC-72. The hydrogen adsorption peak on the Pd/h-PPy electrode is larger than the Pd/s-PPy and Pd/ XC-72 electrodes, verifying the enhanced electrocatalytic performance of the Pd/h-PPy catalyst.
Enormous efforts have been expanded to improve the experimental processes for electrooxidation reactions using a variety of conducting polymers owing to their unique physicochemical and electro-conductive properties; PPy- and polyaniline (PANI)-based composites have been especially deployed as supporting materials for Pd electrocatalysts often entailing the fabrication copolymers of pyrrole and aniline by in situ emulsion polymerization. For example, Ojani and co-workers have reported a catalyst with poly (pyrrole-co-aniline) (PPCA) hollow nanosphere (HN) support functionalized with Pd nanoflowers (Pd NFs/PPCA HN), which has been used in methanol electrooxidation reactions [129]. Herein, the modified electrode catalysts were fabricated via a template-free, one-step method to deposit Pd NFs on PPCA HN coated glassy carbon electrode (GCE) using a simple electrochemically potentiostatic procedure, following the addition of a solution containing Pd(II) ions and sulfuric acid. The TEM and SEM images indicate the dispersion of flower like NPs on the surface of hallow polymers with an average diameter of 90 nm.
The efficiency of Pd NFs/PPCA HN/GCE in oxidation reaction of methanol in alkaline conditions was evaluated by chronoamperometry, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy, and cyclic voltammetry; the electrocatalytic oxidation efficiency was enhanced by using Pd NFs/PPCA HN/GCE as a highly efficient, stable and active catalyst for direct methanol fuel cells.

sections.heading: 3.2.5. Pd NPs supported on amphiphilic polymers
sections.text:
In a separate study, the synthesis of amphiphilic resin of polystyrene-poly(ethylene glycol) (PS-PEG), and dispersion of Pd (ARP-Pd) NPs as the catalyst for hydrodechlorination of chloroarenes and oxidation of alcohols has been performed [130]; steps and preparative procedural details for ARP-Pd catalyst are shown in Scheme 9. The polymeric ligand 2 was prepared through dehydrative condensation of PS-PEG amino resin with bispyridine chelating ligand 1 in the presence of 1-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-
Scheme 9. Synthesis of ARP-Pd catalyst.
Scheme 11. Oxidation reaction of alcohols catalyzed by ARP-Pd in water.
3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride, and 1-hydroxybenzotriazole hydrate in DMF at 25 C. Then, 2 was treated with Pd(II) acetate in toluene for 1 h to achieve the Pd complex 3. Subsequently, Pd (0) complex 4 was synthesized in situ by the reaction of benzyl alcohol and complex 3 in water for 12 h, which readily released neutral Pd. In the final step, Pd NPs were stabilized in PS-PEG resin to acquire the desirable ARP-Pd catalyst.
The as-prepared catalyst acted as a powerful nanocatalyst in hydrodechlorination and oxidation of alcohols in aqueous reaction condition, which provided excellent yields in short reaction times (Schemes 10 and 11); high yield catalytic oxidation of primary and secondary alcohols in H2O was performed in an oxygen atmosphere in the presence of ARP-Pd catalyst to deliver aldehydes and ketones, respectively. Upon completion of the reaction, the ARP-Pd catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture, and reused for 4 runs. The ensuing results show that carboxylic acids were prepared
Scheme 10. Hydrodechlorination reactions catalyzed by ARP-Pd and ammonium formate.
in excellent yields from catalytic aerobic oxidation of primary alcohols such as 1-octanol, 1-hexanol, and 1-butanol in the presence of 0.2 M aqueous solution of potassium carbonate and 20 mol% Pd of the ARP-Pd catalyst under oxygen gas (1 atm.) in refluxing water and reaction time 40 min.
3.2.6. Pd NPs supported on conjugated microporous polymers Conjugated microporous polymers (CMPs) are considered as organic porous polymers having p-conjugated skeletons, consisting of three dimensional networks, which could combine permanent micropores or nanopores. The preparation of nanocatalysts from nanoporous organic polymers fabricated by only covalent bonds has been of interest owing to high thermochemical stability and tunable building units [131–134]. Compared to other polymeric materials, i.e. COFs and MOFs, CMPs generally have superior thermal and chemical stability due to their rigid three-dimensional structure and the presence of building blocks prepared from simple phenyl units to extended arenes, heterocyclic aromatic units and large macrocycles. One of the techniques utilized to develop polymer supported Pd-catalysts is encapsulating Pd NPs by organic
porous polymers e.g. CMPs as exemplified by the synthesis of Pd/ CMP-N2 and -H2 catalysts using Pd catalyzed polymerization reaction [135]. CMPs were obtained through Cooper’s method via Pd catalyzed cross-coupling reaction of 1,3,5-triethynylbenzene with 1,4-diiodobenzene. This compound was modified with Pd(PPh3)4 without the use of copper co-catalyst (Scheme 12). Pd nanocatalyst was then deposited in CMP network in the polymerization process by impregnation of Pd(PPh3)4 as in toluene-NEt3 at 100 C for 72 h and subsequently aggregated to prepare the Pd NPs via thermal treatment in various CMPs such as CMP-1, CMP-2, and CMP-OH.
TEM results confirmed that the ultra-small Pd NPs were formed into CMP frameworks after the thermal treatment; sizes of the Pd NPs were found to be 1.6–3.5 nm. The heterogenized Pd/CMP-N2 and -H2 catalysts were used in the selective hydrogenation of 4- nitrostyrene and oxidation of benzyl alcohol (Table 4); high yields were obtained in the presence of H2 or O2 in dry toluene for 4 h. As shown in Table 4, Pd/CMP-OH-H2 exhibited higher catalytic activity than other catalysts for the oxidation of benzyl alcohol (last entry).

sections.heading: 3.2.7. Pd NPs supported on multiparous polymers
sections.text: Samanta and Nandi designed size-tunable, highly efficient and recyclable Pd NPs based on poly vinylidene fluoride/ethylene carbonate/Pd gel nanostructures as multiparous polymer binder-Pd catalysts [136]. Pd nanocatalysts were prepared by reducing Pd (OAc)2 in different proportions of 0.2%, 0.5%, and 2% (w/w) by thermal decomposition. Subsequently, the dried gel nanocomposites were obtained after the removal of ethylene carbonate and finally the formed Pd NPs were dispersed on poly vinylidene fluoride. TEM measurements revealed spherical and highly dispersed particles with diameters from 3 to 6 nm. The oxidation reaction of benzoin and benzyl alcohol, by Pd nanocomposite as the catalyst and water as the green solvent, afforded 92 and 86% yields, respectively (Scheme 13). In addition, the recyclability of the prepared catalyst was verified up to three consecutive runs with a very small decline of catalytic activity.

sections.heading: 3.2.8. Pd NPs supported on functional resins
sections.text:
Recently, the surface modification of functionalized resins with homogeneously dispersed size-controlled Pd nanoclusters and their application in a few industrial processes has been studied [137]. For example, Kralik and colleagues reported the synthesis
Scheme 12. Synthesis of Pd/CMPs nanocatalyst. (Copyright 2014 E
of a Pd-based catalysts with a gel-type poly-acrylonitrile-N,Ndimethylacrylamide-ethylenedimethacrylate (ADE) and Pd nanostructures [138]. In this work, the chosen resin ADE is a copolymer of N,N-dimethylacrylamide, poly-acrylonitrile, and ethylenedimethacrylate (Fig. 8) and followed by a reaction of pre-swollen ADE with a solution of Na2PdCl4 at room temperature to give a macromolecular complex. Subsequently, the Pd0/ADE nanocomposite was prepared by facile reduction of -CN-PdCl3Na+ microparticles NaBH4 in water at 0 C or 50 C for 30 min. The resulting nanocatalyst contained well-dispersed spherical Pd nanostructures with a diameter of 4 nm. The catalytic activity of obtained Pd0/ADE has been evaluated in the oxidation of nbutanol and benzyl alcohol using dioxygen in water (Table 5); the recyclability of the prepared catalyst was verified up to four consecutive runs.

sections.heading: 3.3. Hydrolytic oxidation reactions
sections.text:
One of the most attractive methods for biomass refining and organic functional group transformations is the execution of catalytic reactions in biphasic media consisting mostly of hydrophobic organic solvent and water [140,141]. In this regard, metal NPs functionalized vesicles have been extensively used to prepare Pickering interfacial catalysts (PICs) emulsifying agents to consolidate water droplets dispersion in chloroform [141,142]. In fact, this method is aimed at combining excellent activity and selectivity for homogeneous amphiphilic and catalytically active colloidal species such as Au and Pd NPs with the simplicity of products separation and reuse of the heterogeneous catalysts. An example is provided by Shankar et al. in 2017, in which a series of Pd-based PICs were prepared using polyisobornyl methacrylate45 (PiBMA)b-polydimethylsiloxane75 (PDMS)-b-PiBMA amphiphilic block
Scheme 23. The preparation of poly(methylmethacrylate) supported b-diketonelinked Pd catalysts.
Scheme 24. Plausible mechanism for olefin oxidation reaction catalyzed by
copolymer as a Pickering emulsifier and it’s self-assembly at water chloroform interface (Scheme 16) [143]. This method relies upon surface modification of Pd NPs with PiBMA45-b-PDMS75-bPiBMA45 amphiphilic block copolymer to infix a dispersion of water droplets in chloroform and it’s self-assembly at waterCHCl3 interface. Subsequently, stable Pd nanoclusters were formed via ultrasonication of aqueous Pd(OAc)2 with triethylsilane and polymer in CHCl3.
The cross dehydrocoupling of primary organosilanes, RSiH3, and water at 80 C was carried out using Pd-PIC catalyst (Scheme 17). The main advantages of this catalytic system are the stability and recyclability of the nanocatalyst for the preparation of high molecular weight poly(hydrosiloxane).

sections.heading: 3.4. Epoxidation reactions
sections.text:
The formation of Au NPs and Au-Pd nanoalloys supported on resins as catalysts and their catalytic performance in epoxidation reactions has been evaluated [144]; the method for the fabrication of Pd-catalyst is presented in Scheme 18. Swelling of cross-linked polystyrene resin was conducted in the presence of HAuCl4 and Pd(OAc)2 in ethanol. Subsequently, the bimetallic NPs supported on this resin were prepared by sorption-reduction to provide Au-Pd NPs@Resin as a reusable, novel and effective nanocatalyst. EDX results of Au-Pd NPs@Resin catalyst presented the presence of Au and Pd NPs in catalyst and the TEM micrographs ascertained well dispersed spherical particles with an average size of less than 5 nm in a resin bed.
The Au-Pd NPs@Resin nanocatalyst, which was applied for epoxidation reactions of various styrene derivatives in liquid phase utilizing molecular oxygen as a green oxidant and 1,4-dioxane as the solvent at 80 C for 16 h, illustrated high activity and selectivity for the preparation of epoxide products in moderate to excellent yields (Scheme 19). The results showed that 1/1 molar ratio of Au-Pd NPs has potential catalytic ability in 98% conversion of styrene to styrene oxide with selectivity of 75% and turnover number
poly(methylmethacrylate) supported b-diketone-linked Pd complexes.
(TON) of 0.181 (s 1) with a proposed mechanism depicted in Scheme 20. Inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy analysis of the reused catalyst revealed slight alterations in Pd and Au contents (0.00387 and 0.00305 mmol/g, respectively), without metal leaching of supported polymeric catalyst.

sections.heading: 3.5. Hydrazine electrooxidation
sections.text:
In another study, well dispersed Pd NPs were stabilized on the poly(o-phenylenediamine) (PoPD) colloids via controlled reduction pathway and used for oxidation of hydrazine [145]. PoPD submicrospheres were fabricated by chemical polymerization of ophenylenediamine monomers using aqueous solution of ammonium persulfate at ambient temperature. Nanocatalyst (Pd/P2) was prepared by synthesis of PoPD colloids through chemical polymerization of o-phenylenediamine monomers using aqueous solution of ammonium persulfate at ambient temperature via effective chemical reduction in a two-step route, followed by a reaction with an aqueous solution of PdCl42 to form the PoPD-PdCl42 conjugated structure. Then, PoPD was oxidized with concurrent reduction of Pd2+ ions to Pd0 (Pd/P1) (Fig. 9). Subsequently, Pd/P1 was reduced with ascorbic acid to afford the desired Pd/P2 catalyst. In this work,
Scheme 25. Synthesis of polymer
Scheme 26. Oxidation of olefins catalyzed by
Pd NPs could be anchored and immobilized using the amino functional group of PoPD submicrospheres without any additional surfactants. EDX studies confirmed the presence of Pd NPs in the synthesized catalyst and the SEM images of the obtained nanocatalyst showed well-dispersed Pd NPs with an average size of 10 nm in the polymer matrix. The resulting Pd/P2 catalyst demonstrated high catalytic activity in the hydrazine electrooxidation reactions.
3.6. Benzene oxidation
The control of porous structural features through pyrolysis methods has been exemplified by a catalyst for the complete benzene oxidation based on Pd NPs-supported on porous polyhedron tricobalt tetraoxide (Pd/Co3O4) through MOF pyrolysis [146]. In this approach, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks were fabricated by incorporating 2-methylimidazole in methanol and cobalt nitrate hexahydrate. A series of porous polyhedron Co3O4 supports were then synthesized via direct pyrolysis of Co-based zeolitic imidazolate scaffolds. Subsequently, the one-step calcination of these compounds at 250, 350, and 550 C gave Co3O4-PP-250, Co3O4-NP350, and Co3O4-PP-550, respectively. The NP size and proper
-anchored metal complexes.

porosity of nanocatalyst can be controlled by adjusting the calcination temperature.

sections.heading: 4. Polymeric Pd complexes for oxidation reactions
sections.text:
Among the most practical supports, polymer containing Pd species are versatile, efficient, and heterogeneous catalysts for a broad range of oxidation reactions owing to their thermal stability, reusability, and high catalytic performance. Over the past years, macromolecular supports have received significant attention with respect to the improvement of experimental techniques for immobilization of homogeneous metallic complexes; the activity of var-
Scheme 27. Oxidation reactions of alcohols catalyzed by polymer-functionalized Pd(II) complex.
Scheme 28. Synthesis of polymer-suppor
ious heterogeneous metal complexes have been modulated using polymeric supports [147–149].

sections.heading: 4.1. Oxidation of olefins and alcohols
sections.text:
4.1.1. Polystyrene supported b-diketone linked Pd complex Nair et al. synthesized a Pd catalyst with b-diketone ligand on polystyrene with varying degrees of cross-linking via a suspension polymerization method and studied their catalytic activity, selectivity and stability of the as-prepared catalyst in oxidation of olefins [150]. The b-diketone-linked Pd complexes supported on polystyrene having different methylene spacers and cross-linking were synthesized via modulating the monomer ratios in five steps (Scheme 21). Compound 1 with different cross-link densities of 5, 10 and 15 was prepared from the reaction of styrene and divinyl benzene monomers with benzoyl peroxide as the initiator. Compound 2 having one, three and five methylene spacers was synthesized under different conditions. Compound 3 was then synthesized from the esterification of 2 in absolute ethanol and concentrated H2SO4 at 80 C for 12 h. Subsequently, compound 4 was prepared via the reaction of 3 with 40-methylacetophenone in acetonitrile at refluxing temperature. In the last step, compound 4 was exposed to Pd(II) salt to afford the desired polystyrene supported, b-diketone linked Pd catalyst (5).
The obtained Pd complex with five methylene spacer arms acted as an efficient catalyst in the oxidation of olefins in methanol-H2O medium for 10 h using CuCl2 as the co-oxidant; carbonyl compounds were acquired in good to high yields under refluxing condition (Scheme 22). In this study, the effect of the spacer groups between the metal complex and the polymer matrix, the structural environment of the ligand, and the degree of
ted Pd(II) secondary amine complex.
Scheme 29. Oxidation of cyclohexene, styrene and other organic substrates catalyzed by P-[Pd2(seam)2(OAc)2].
Scheme 30. Wacker-type oxidation of alkenes catalyzed by polymer supported Pd(II).
cross-linking on the catalytic performance have been studied. Additionally, reusability enquiries of the prepared catalyst in oxidation reactions revealed that the polymeric complexes could be recycled for five runs with negligible decline in their catalytic activity.
4.1.2. Poly(methylmethacrylate)-supported b-diketone-linked Pd complex
In another study, the same group have proposed a simple method for the fabrication of a catalyst for the oxidation of olefins to their carbonyl derivatives based on b-diketone linked Pd-supported on poly(methyl methacrylate) via suspension polymerization [151]. A fixed ligand system was fabricated by immobilizing 40-methylacetophenone to the surface of cross-linked poly (methyl methacrylate) resin for coordination with Pd(II) (Scheme 23). The oxidation of olefins occurred using CuCl2 in H2O-CH3OH at 70 C for 10 h in the presence of poly(methylmethacrylate) supported, b-diketone-linked Pd complexes as the catalyst afforded carbonyl compounds. CuCl2 co-oxidant was reduced to Cu(I), which can be reoxidized to Cu(II) in the presence of air; mechanistic schematic representation for olefin oxidation is depicted in Scheme 24. In this work, the structural environment of the ligand and the degree of cross-linking of the polymer matrix affected on the catalytic activity and stability were investigated. After completion of the oxidation reactions, the catalyst was separated and recycled for three runs with no significant loss of activity.

sections.heading: 4.1.3. Chloromethylated poly(styrene-divinyl benzene) supported metal(II) complexes
sections.text:
The assimilation of metal complexes into the rigid polymer supportshasbeencarriedout toapply theprivilegesof theheterogeneous catalytic systems, simplework-up and reusability. Along this line, the immobilization of various metal(II) complexes (Co, Cu, and Pd) onto the surface of polymeric supports has been reported by Islamand colleagues [152]. They anchored anthranilic acid on the chloromethylated poly(styrene-divinyl benzene) and finished the formation of complex catalysts by treatment with chloro salts of palladium(II), cobalt(II), and copper(II) ions in ethanol at 70 C (Scheme 25). The application of polymer-anchored Pd(II), Cu(II), and Co(II) complexes as highly efficient catalysts was investigated in oxidation of olefins and aromatic alcohols using tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP). The FESEM image of Pd(II) catalyst on the functionalized polymer displayed a smooth surface of polymer-anchored ligand loaded bymetal particles. EDX results showed the presence of Pd particles along with chlorine and oxygen in the catalyst.
The liquid-phase oxidation of olefins including cyclohexene, styrene, cyclooctene, and limonene with tert-butylhydroperoxide as an oxidant, in acetonitrile as a solvent, at 50 C catalyzed by polymer-anchored Pd(II) complexes, delivered selectively epoxides in yields of 69, 74, 100, and 52%, respectively (Scheme 26). Furthermore, polymer-functionalized Pd(II) complex was utilized in the oxidation of aromatic alcohols with tert-butylhydroperoxide in acetonitrile at 80 C to yield aromatic aldehydes in 6 h (Scheme 27). Under optimized reaction conditions, 71% conversion of cyclohexene and 73% conversion of benzyl alcohol could be obtained with Pd(II) catalysts. At the final stage of every oxidation reaction, the tested catalysts were recycled. The complexes were filtered, washed with solvent, and reused for at least 5 times without loss of initial catalytic activity.

sections.heading: 4.1.4. Polystyrene supported Pd(II) complex
sections.text:
In another study, polystyrene-functionalized secondary amine Pd(II) complex (P-[Pd2(seam)2(OAc)2]) was prepared and its catalytic activity was verified in the oxidation of organic substrates [153]. Here, the P-[Pd2(seam)2(OAc)2] complex (F) was prepared from the reaction of a polymer-anchored secondary amine ligand
(E) with Pd(OAc)2 in acetic acid medium (Scheme 28). Generally, the design and synthesis of polystyrene-anchored secondary amine ligands with uniform micropores as catalyst supports show a successful procedure to enhance the efficiency and application of the designed catalysts. The smooth surface of polymer supports was roughened by the functionalization of ligands and spherical metal particles were visualized by SEM images.
The resulting Pd(II) complex was catalytically active for the oxidation of several alcohols and olefins in acetonitrile using tertbutylhydroperoxide as an oxidant at 60 C, resulting in the desired products with high yields and TON (Scheme 29). In addition, the stabilization of Pd on polymeric framework not only enhanced the catalyst performance, product selectivity, and stability, but also enabled simple recycling of P-[Pd2(seam)2(OAc)2] catalyst for at least seven cycles. In this research, the effects of different parameters on the catalytic activity and consistency of Pd(II) catalyst have been studied by controlling the oxidant, solvent, reaction time, temperature, and catalyst amounts.

sections.heading: 4.2. Wacker-type oxidations
sections.text: The immobilization of Pd(II) catalyst onto the surface of solid polymeric supports carrying nitrile(cyanomethyl) ligands has been reported by Tang and Sherrington [154]. These supported Pd(II) catalysts comprise one polystyrene skeleton, five polybenzimidazole backbones, and finally, a polyacrylonitrile backbone. The obtained polymer supported Pd(II) catalysts were effectively applied in Wacker-type oxidation of dec-1-ene employing CuCl2 as a co-catalyst, affording the methyl ketone products in high yields (Scheme 30). The recycling experiments were performed in the oxidation reaction, after separation of catal-1 and -5 and washing with EtOH. The catalyst was reused in the next run without any additional Cu(II) and could be recycled six times with a small decrease of catalytic activity and barely noticeable Pd leaching ( 1 ppm).

sections.heading: 5. Results and discussion
sections.text: The polymer-supported Pd catalysts used in the various oxidation reactions are summarized in Table 6. After scrutiny of the related publications, it became apparent that there is no special rule to theoretically predict the result of a catalytic reaction process. For obtaining better results compared to the other similar works, it usually amounts to the characteristics of the catalyst such as surface area, size of the catalyst, composition of the catalyst, its morphology, preparation methods etc. Generally, this comparison depends on the reaction conditions and has apparently no predictive rule.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion and future prospects
sections.text:
Despite advantages of homogenous catalysts such as high reactivity and selectivity, they have often failed for commercialization because of difficulties encountered while attempting to separate and reuse the expensive noble metals. These disadvantages and
some industrial problems such as corrosion and deposition on the reactor walls strongly restrict their potential application in large scale syntheses particularly because of environmental and economic concerns. The heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts on solid supports is an emerging and important area of research in heterogeneous catalysis. Catalysts derived from or immobilized on polymers have garnered continual attention and appeared as pivotal catalysts for a large number of catalytic systems due to their unusual properties such as small particle size, thermal stability, and high surface area. This review has highlighted some significant aspects of these growing research areas towards understanding the potential uses of polymer supported Pd catalysts. Although Pd is the most commonly deployed catalyst in oxidation reactions but Pd catalysts have some drawbacks typical of homogeneous catalysts such as difficulties in quantitative separation (purity of the product), recovery, and regeneration of the catalyst. Immobilization of catalysts on solid supports is one of the ideal means to improve the efficiency and recovery of catalysts. To prevent the agglomeration of Pd NPs and the overstoichiometric use of homogeneous Pd reagents, polymers have been used as a support for Pd NPs. The preparation of Pd nanocatalysts and complexes supported on polymeric materials has introduced new dimension for catalysis because of their high activity, selectivity, stability and reusability in catalytic transformations. This high performance can be attributed to the excellent properties of nanostructured materials such as surface area, size of the particles, composition of the catalyst, its morphology, preparation methods and unique features of the polymeric substances such as good chemical and thermal stability, low cost, low toxicity, ease of handling, and high reusability. Pd catalysts are known to interact with some polymeric materials and can catalyze a variety of oxidation reactions, which necessitates the use of transition metals such as Pd. The deployment of environmentally benign oxidants and eco-friendly solvents and the inherently high activity in various oxidation reactions and their reuse with a considerable efficiency are additional attributes. The synthesis and applications of polymer-supported Pd catalysts appear to circumvent some of
the common drawbacks namely hazardous oxidants and reagents and toxic solvents and offer cost effective and selective protocols. According to the results from the mentioned papers in this review, oxidation reaction using polymer-supported Pd catalysts have been tested several times to ensure reproducibility and the reported results are generally highly reproducible. There are some important industrial processes that are catalyzed homogeneously, however, they are less frequently preferred in industry than heterogeneous catalysts as they must be separated from the reaction mixture, an expensive proposition. Despite the advantages of polymer-supported Pd catalysts such as high catalytic activity and selectivity, some of the processes have not been commercialized because of difficulties encountered in their preparation; industrial problems are especially encountered due to the high cost which strongly restrict their potential application particular because of environmental and economic concerns. In general, industrial scale production of appropriate, effective and cheap catalysts requires the removal of several barriers in the synthesis of polymer-supported Pd catalysts on an experimental scale. However, despite these recent advancements in polymer-supported Pd nanocatalysts, a series of challenges still need to be addressed in future:
Development and utilization of earth-abundant biopolymers such as lignin, collagen, cellulose, starch, cellulose, chitin, alginate, polypeptide, pectin, gum, chitosan etc. [155]. The use of aqueous and alcoholic extracts of plants and other biological resources for the preparation of Pd NPs and their stabilization on the polymers under mild and greener conditions that is both, economically beneficial and safe for human health and the environment. Development of novel and greener methods exploiting the use of various biowastes in the design of polymer-supported Pd nanocatalysts preferably under solvent-free conditions [155]. Development of magnetic polymer-supported Pd NPs or complexes with excellent catalytic activity and reusability in oxidation reactions under mild conditions. Development and utilization of mild and inexpensive oxidants in oxidation reactions. Development and utilization of simple one-step methods and inexpensive reagents for the industrial scale synthesis of polymer-supported Pd NPs or complexes. Biomass conversion towards high value-added products via oxidation reactions using polymer-supported Pd NPs or complexes [155].
Thus, the chance to fabricate advanced heterogeneous catalysts with high catalytic activity and selectivity is a key issue to researchers in order to improve the oxidation reactions in the future.

metadata.abstractText: This review describes the recent advances in the fabrication, characterization and applications of palladium nanoparticles (Pd NPs)/complexes supported on polymers. Nanostructured materials and NPs of various natures, shapes and sizes in combination with polymers, provide unique physicochemical properties and significant potential applications. An overview in catalysis encompassing the preparation of polymer-supported Pd nanocatalysts and Pd complexes for the oxidation of alcohols, olefins, alkenes, carbon monoxide, etc. is presented. Heterogeneous oxidation catalysis, a vital tool in chemical synthesis and transformations, includes the development of various synthetic strategies for the fabrication of Pd-based catalysts; eminent role played by polymer supports in the morphological and structural properties of the ensuing catalysts, is highlighted. 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
